name: OXYBUTYNIN
comment: In particular, oxybutynin has consistently been shown to cause deterioration in memory

name: RISPERIDONE
comment: This retrospective study demonstrates that risperidone appears to be efficacious in the treatment of clinically significant positive and negative symptoms in patients with AD.

name: TELMISARTAN
comment: Researchers believe telmisartan can slow the progression of Alzheimer’s by controlling blood flow

name: BEXAROTENE
comment: Bexarotene therapy ameliorates behavioral deficits and induces functional and molecular changes in very-old Triple Transgenic Mice model of Alzheimer´s disease

name: CLOTRIMAZOLE
comment: MCZ treatment significantly attenuated cognitive impairment, suppressed iNOS and cyclooxygenase-2 expression, and activation of astrocyte and microglial BV2 cells

name: SUVOREXANT
comment: FDA approved for insomnia in AD

name: AGOMELATINE
comment: Agomelatine is effective on improving behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia, no matter in depression, sleep disturbance, delusion, hallucination, or aggression

name: DROPERIDOL
comment: Commonly given as sedative in emergency medicine

name: RIMONABANT
comment: Associated with an increased risk of anxiety, depression, and suicide.

name: AMOXAPINE
comment: Taken together, our study suggests that amoxapine, though no longer a first-line drug for the treatment of depression, may be beneficial for AD

name: LEUPROLIDE
comment: These data indicate that cognitive function is preserved in patients treated with high dose Lupron who were already using AChEIs. The positive interaction between Lupron and AChEIs warrants further investigation for the treatment of AD.

name: BENZTROPINE
comment: A robust association between some classes of anticholinergic drugs and future dementia incidence was observed.

name: ROSIGLITAZONE
comment: Rosiglitazone has a neutral effect on the risk of dementia in type 2 diabetes patients

name: CLOSANTEL
comment: Toxic

name: MIFEPRISTONE
comment: Failed AD trial

name: PREDNISOLONE
comment: Failed AD trial

name: FASIGLIFAM
comment: Liver toxicity

name: MURAGLITAZAR
comment: Adverse events in trials

name: SILDENAFIL
comment: Trials in the making

name: PRANLUKAST
comment: Trial of close analog MONTELUKAST in progress

name: TARANABANT
comment: Serious CNS side effects

name: TELCAGEPANT
comment: Liver toxicity

name: PROPRANOLOL
comment: Overall, these data further strengthen the potential of propranolol as a therapeutic agent for AD.

name: SEGLITIDE
comment: Serious side effects

name: KISSPEPTIN-10
comment: These results suggest that KP peptides are neuroprotective against Aβ, IAPP, and PrP peptides via a receptor independent action involving direct binding to the amyloid peptides.

name: CLOZAPINE
comment: This study suggests that as one of candidate for multi-target approach of AD treatment, clozapine is proposed as a therapeutic drug for treatment of AD patients.

name: ISTRADEFYLLINE
comment: Moreover, in amyloid plaque-bearing mice, low-dose istradefylline treatment enhanced spatial memory and habituation

name: ERGOTAMINE
comment: This study offers DHEC not only as a new chemical moiety for selectively modulating the activity of γ-secretase but also a candidate for drug repositioning in Alzheimer’s disease.

name: ALMOREXANT
comment: Potential liver toxicity

name: BROMOCRIPTINE
comment: AD clinical trial in progress

name: BUPRENORPHINE
comment: Addictive opioid

name: ROLOFYLLINE
comment: Seizures and stroke in trial

name: HALOPERIDOL
comment: Haloperidol (2–3 mg/d) decreased psychosis and disruptive behaviours in Alzheimer's disease although 20% of patients developed moderate to severe extrapyramidal side effects.

name: ZAFIRLUKAST
comment: Trial of close analog MONTELUKAST in progress

name: ALFUZOSIN
comment: The results suggest that tamsulosin for BPH is not associated with worsening of the cognitive decline in patients with AD.

name: CARVEDILOL
comment: AD clinical trial in progress

name: MONTELUKAST
comment: AD clinical trial in progress
